As always a hammer is not the only solution for all carpenter=E2=80=99s pro=
blems.  Know your tools, and know your IDE.  IDEs like Eclipse and IntelliJ=
 make it very easy to generate an interface from an existing class or vice =
versa.  I do not see any problems using Interfaces where it makes sense. =
=20

=20

I remember situations where the development manager demanded that all meth=
ods are private except the few that the client is supposed to use.  That de=
mand together with the dislike of Interfaces then asked for usage of JUnit =
extensions like Junitx (I think that is the name) which allow to test priva=
te methods (or to write my own reflection method retrieval for testing the =
privats).  Using Interfaces in that case would have improved the whole situ=
ation.

=20

Andreas

Andreas Guther wrote:
> There is always the possibility to define your API with Interfaces and t=
hus have it as user friendly as possible without exposing any additional me=
thods that were written in the actual implementation for the purpose of tes=
ting the class.
>=20

YUCK! That's like making your tech support user friendly by outsourcing=20
it to trained professionasl in India rather than letting your clients=20
talk directly to the developers. There's a ton of theory (i.e.=20
rationalizations) to support doing that, and it's completely=20
counterproductive in practice.

Interfaces are very popular among the most theoretical programmers: i.e.=
=20
exactly the sort of programmers who are likely to write books, read=20
books about OO theory, and hang out on lists like this one. However in=20
my experience concrete classes are much simpler and much preferred by=20
the vast majority of pragmatic programmers just getting their jobs done.

I can certainly see how making a class test-friendly could make it less=20
caller-friendly. In fact, exactly how to do that is the subject of=20
another perma-thread on this list. exposing methods purely for the=20
convenience of testers expands a class's interface and makes it harder=20
to learn, use, and understand. Minimal interfaces are simpler to=20
understand and learn. Exposing additional methods purely for test=20
convenience is very counter-productive to caller-convenience. The only=20
public parts of a class's interface should be things that are relevant=20
to client programmers.
